definitions.definition: used to show where somebody/something starts

examples.text: She began to walk away from him.
Has the train from Bristol arrived?

definitions.definition: used to show what the origin of somebody/something is

examples.text: I'm from Italy.
documents from the sixteenth century
quotations from Shakespeare
heat from the sun

definitions.definition: used to show who sent or gave something/somebody

examples.text: an email from my brother
information from witnesses
the man from *(= representing)* the insurance company

definitions.definition: used to show when something starts

examples.text: We're open from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day.
He was blind from birth.

definitions.definition: used to show how far apart two places are

examples.text: 100 metres from the scene of the accident

definitions.definition: used to show somebody’s position or point of view

examples.text: You can see the island from here.
From a financial point of view the project was a disaster.

definitions.definition: used to show the range of something

examples.text: The temperature varies from 30 degrees to minus 20.
The store sells everything from shoelaces to computers.
Conditions vary from school to school.

definitions.definition: used to show the state or form of something/somebody before a change

examples.text: Things have gone **from bad to worse**.
translating from English to Spanish
You need a break from routine.

definitions.definition: used when making or recognizing a difference between two people or things

examples.text: Is Portuguese very different from Spanish?
I can't tell one twin from the other.

definitions.definition: used to show the material that something is made of

examples.text: Steel is made from iron.

definitions.definition: used to show that somebody/something is separated or removed

examples.text: The party was ousted from power after eighteen years.

definitions.definition: used to show that something is prevented

examples.text: She saved him from drowning.

definitions.definition: used to show the reason for something

examples.text: She felt sick from tiredness.

definitions.definition: used to show the reason for making a judgement

examples.text: You can tell a lot about a person from their handwriting.
From what I heard the company's in deep trouble.

definitions.definition: starting at the time mentioned and continuously after that

examples.text: **From now on** you can work on your own.
She never spoke to him again from that day on.

wordOrigin: Old English fram, from, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse frá (see fro).
